urls.title: Tales from The Leeds Library: Special Oral History Episode with Judith Pickard
urls.description: In this special episode of Tales from The Leeds Library, Archive Assistant Niimi Day Gough and Assistant Librarian Anna Goodridge interview our longest subscribing member. Miss Judith Pickard became a member in 1952 - which, at the time, required references and a share certificate (viewable on our social medias @theleedslibrary)! To celebrate her 70th anniversary of joining the Library, she shares her memories of sherry parties, piano recitals, and the Library's growth towards its Next Chapter. To find out more about The Leeds Library's exciting expansion into our new building, and to view the plans we discuss in the episode, click here. Our entrance and exit music is Book Bag by E's Jammy Jams.

data.text: Earlier this year, we spoke to our longest-subscribing member, Miss Pickard, whose membership began on 2nd September 1952. She shares her memories of sherry parties, piano recitals, and the Library’s growth towards its Next Chapter https://t.co/PvgE2OTB2u https://t.co/ZFQLhOrBkZ

urls.title: Leeds Lit Fest
urls.description: Leeds Lit Fest 2023 is back! Join us from Saturday 25 Feb - Sunday 5 March. Returning for its fifth year, the city’s award-winning festival of words and thought will take place across a diverse range of the city’s spaces and aims to bring together, and help develop, the city’s literary scene, with writers, poets and performers from the UK and beyond. This year’s festival will tie in with Leeds 2023, the citywide celebration of culture and will interweave themes of untold stories, radical acts, playful adventures and future generations The festival which is organised by a number of cultural organisations in the city, will engage audiences in over 50 events aimed to appeal not just to lovers of books and the written word but also to appeal to audiences who would never normally consider going to a literature festival. This eclectic approach to the programme will see comedy, cabaret, a literature quiz, film screening, art exhibition, theatre performance, a literature walk and creative work

urls.title: March 2022: Melissa Fu : The Leeds Centre for New Chinese Writing
urls.description: Melissa Fu grew up in Northern New Mexico and now lives near Cambridge, UK, with her husband and children. With academic backgrounds in physics and English, she has worked in education as a teacher, curriculum developer, and consultant. Melissa was the regional winner of the Words and Women 2016 Prose Competition and was a 2017 Apprentice with the London-based Word Factory. In 2018/2019, Melissa was the David TK Wong Fellow at the University of East Anglia. Peach Blossom Spring is her first novel. This

urls.title: The Leeds Library
urls.description: Founded in 1768 as a proprietary subscription library and is now the oldest surviving example of this sort of library in the British Isles.

tweets.text:
People of Leeds—it's been a pleasure chatting to you this week! Pop by the next time you're in town, and follow us @theleedslibrary. And on our website you can find out about what's going on at Leeds' oldest cultural institution 📚🎙✍️

https://t.co/Rr48qyrskQ https://t.co/x8OExwAESG
The New Room is 141 years old, but it's still the new room. The photograph on the left was taken 100 years ago, in 1922. The one on the right is a couple of years old... https://t.co/ZYSOLP4PDK
@PeopleofLeeds or possibly an arch made of Leeds writers.
@annaonscreen @theleedslibrary @simonfairbanks @GhostStoryFest See you there? 😉👻

Today's book is our most recent hostoric acquisition—kindly donated by one of our members. It's also now the smallest item in our collection. It's a Book of Common Prayer, and it accompanied the donor's great uncle throughout his service in the First World War. https://t.co/XPk69BQvGN

urls.title: Tales from The Leeds Library: Special Oral History Episode with Judith Pickard
urls.description: In this special episode of Tales from The Leeds Library, Archive Assistant Niimi Day Gough and Assistant Librarian Anna Goodridge interview our longest subscribing member. Miss Judith Pickard became a member in 1952 - which, at the time, required references and a share certificate (viewable on our social medias @theleedslibrary)! To celebrate her 70th anniversary of joining the Library, she shares her memories of sherry parties, piano recitals, and the Library's growth towards its Next Chapter. To find out more about The Leeds Library's exciting expansion into our new building, and to view the plans we discuss in the episode, click here. Our entrance and exit music is Book Bag by E's Jammy Jams.

tweets.text: Earlier this year, we spoke to our longest-subscribing member, Miss Pickard, whose membership began on 2nd September 1952. She shares her memories of sherry parties, piano recitals, and the Library’s growth towards its Next Chapter https://t.co/PvgE2OTB2u https://t.co/ZFQLhOrBkZ

Today's book of the day is our copy of Elizabeth Raffald's 'The Experienced English Housekeeper', printed in Manchester in 1769. It's part of the fascinating life of the author—a writer, innovator, and entrepreneur 🧵 1/4 https://t.co/P21x3PFV67
Very excited that @theleedslibrary is hosting this event next Tuesday. Link to tickets below! https://t.co/dJWrSPLKS0

urls.title: Chelping with Cecilia Knapp & Rommi Smith
urls.description: November's Chelping sees two more fantastic guests + open mic-ers with Matt Abbott

tweets.text:
🎤 please note that the open mic section for this month's #Chelping at @theleedslibrary event is now FULL. there is a reserve list, but we can no longer guarantee anybody a slot. apologies for any disappointment.

tickets available below for £5!
https://t.co/gItfT1zytL https://t.co/6upQ7UIp9Q

Synchronicity: Valerie Fletcher Eliot, whom I am writing a book about, used to read at @theleedslibrary, while my other project is updating The Great Good Place - a topic discussed here by the CEO of the library that was so important to the Fletchers. https://t.co/aRlTtevDHZ

urls.title: Peach Blossom Spring: Melissa Fu and Jennifer Wong in Conversation
urls.description: With every misfortune there is a blessing and within every blessing, the seeds of misfortune, and so it goes, until the end of time.

tweets.text: We're delighted to be welcoming @MelissaLFu and @jennywcreative to Leeds on Nov 12th, 5pm, to talk about Melissa's novel Peach Blossom Spring, in partnership with @theleedslibrary. All welcome! More details here: https://t.co/vCsOfR5oxR https://t.co/fw6yi0OKOA

urls.title: Three daggers drawn: Yorkshire crime fiction triple launch
urls.description: Murder…History…Yorkshire. What could go wrong?

tweets.text:
Tomorrow night it's a murder of Yorkshire crime writers: @FrancesBrody , @rowancoleman and, well, me, at @theleedslibrary . Oh yeah, they'll have a bar. Turn up or book here - it's free.
https://t.co/zyNZWhGhJB
